text: Okay, the tapes were on. Mark, could you give me a little bit of your background, how you grew up, and maybe how you got interested in writing, and what kind of science backgrounds you might have had that might have pointed you towards science fiction eventually? Sure. I was born in 1946 in New Jersey, and grew up in the suburbs outside of Philadelphia. I'd say that probably my interest in the literary matters got started when I was in grade school, junior high school, my mother was a college level English teacher, taught at Penn State, I believe the University of Georgia. So I pretty much had a lot of books around at all times, and was encouraged to direct my interest in that direction. As far as starting writing goes, that was almost seemed to be the thing to do. When I was in grade school and began writing short stories, it was a good play and release for imagination, and I certainly enjoyed it, and the editors didn't share my enthusiasm, however, and I have had not entirely a lot of success in short stories, and that effect the only one I've ever published was Soul, when I finally got out here to Idaho in any event, I wrote Amateur Status as a hobby of ultra junior high and high school, and then when I got into college, I was very fortunate to go to a place called Kenyon College in Ohio, which has really quite a history. My area of study has always been the liberal arts, the sciences I'm frankly trying to be much too challenging and much too much work. What I do as a science fiction only in the sense that it's I'd say more fantasy than science fiction. I don't really have that much of a grasp of hard science, not both but I certainly appreciate the aesthetics of it, and that figures in, I take a great deal in the four novels of the effort. I was very fortunate at Kenyon because I finally decided that this was not going to sell short stories, and in my sophomore year began my first novel which was sold at the end of my junior year, and came out with paperbacks, words of starship in the fall of 1967 that apparently survived in the marketplace, since being reprinted in England, Holland, not Holland, I'm sorry, England, France, Italy, and Germany. I've had the others. And I wrote another one my senior year in college. One of the Kenyon Review Prize for Achievement in Fiction, I think primarily because it was the only college student writing novel that everybody else was pulling around with poetry and short stories. I won a scholarship to the New York University Law School, a Root-Hilton scholarship, and that fact was free, pretty much determined my career choice, and because at no time was I under the illusion that gainful living could be gotten from pursuing writing. Now that's maybe either a very good, cold, rational judgment on my part, or pure cowardice in any event, I did go to New York, went through law school, wrote a third novel, the shortest one, The Days Tars There, and while I was there spent the summer of my second year with the legal department of Boise Cascade Corporation out here in Boise, met the law firm that I joined after getting out of law school, and I've been with ever since. Since coming out to Boise, I wrote just one other novel, that short story I mentioned, but one other novel, The Siege of Wonder, and that was published by Double Day in 1976, and then I think by DAW in paperback the next year, and that I think is the best so far. After that was published, I became married to a very wonderful woman, Marika, who already had two very wonderful children when I met her, and that has taken on some immediate responsibility. Also, it's become a partner in the law firm, and I've seen how everybody's, well not everybody, take that back. A lot of people expect you to be fairly grown up, fairly grown up, use the people don't like science, it doesn't mean that people don't like science fiction or reading or writing, but they do expect to pay a little more attention to the job at hand than speculating over your own personal fantasies. Anyway, for whatever reason there is, already has kind of gotten lost in the early burleys of work, and since that time I'm really embarrassed to say that I have not completed anything of any substance. The hope is still there, and I have what I believe to be, I hope will be a viable idea for another novel, and I've been pitching at it now for some time, and can speak with as much a matter of trying to find a new focus, because I believe that a lot of what I've already written was threatening to become repetitious and self-cliché, and also just trying to do some new things. So that makes it perhaps a doubly difficult to get started, and to stick with it, maintain the mood, well I guess first of all I have to find the new mood before I can maintain it. And that's where it stands right now. Okay, I was laughing whenever you were talking about growing up. I'm two years younger than you, and I too have a real life job, and I don't know what it means, have to appear to be grown up anyway. What I want to do now is go back over the individual works, and see what we can dig out, the things that were interesting to discuss, and I need to turn an amplifier down. Okay, now I can hear much better. You allow that you had been writing since a fairly early age in grade school, in fact, and yet science never did, or it interested you, but not the nuts and bolts. When you did start writing, why was it science fiction and not historical fiction or mainstream novels or something else? What was the attraction of science fantasy, I guess is probably what you really write. Great, well I guess the sheer wonder of it, first of all, for an adolescent imagination, it was a very easy one to slip into. An easy genre to slip into. It did not require you to embarrass yourself particularly much by trying to do things that you had no idea how they functioned, writing about them, like girls. It provided a great deal of play, because you could allow your imagination to free reign. So I guess it was kind of self-indulgent in that sense. And that's the way that my imagination seems to work. It took a very peculiar, I thought, an individualized perspective that wanted to express some I hope of, will not turn out to have been just a limited number of ideas and feelings, and fantasy seemed to be best suited to it. Also, the combination of fantasy and science fiction allowed me to work at, even then I think, an element of irony and contradiction, which I've always enjoyed, and which is I think you've got to be pretty talented, much more than I, to do it in a real-world situation, historical or mainstream fiction. There's also another thing, I guess, for I find humor very difficult. I cry myself in normal life, having a very good sense of humor. But the writings, none of the books are at least as jolly, I'm afraid to say. And the contradiction in irony, and I suppose allowed for a reservoir of I guess, bitterness to just get out on the outside and express itself, and to operate in these half-crippled contradictory worlds that I just naturally seem drawn to. Like I said, I hope I'm not going to stay there forever, I certainly don't want to. But it had a very peculiar allure to me. And also, it was completely out of step, but what contemporary adolescent society was saying was to literally, sensitive kids ought to be doing, so they're trying to do the exact opposite. And try to offend my peers, I think I've succeeded on one more occasion when I should but that was the fortunate thing about going to Kenyon because that was very tolerant, I think, one of the two genuinely eccentric stimulating places I've been to. So that's, also, I'll bring up one more thing, the works that the books that I was reading at the time, of the novels that I was thoroughly impressed by were included to Bradbury's work and later on to College Tolkien and on TV, of course, it's very favored to Twilight Zone, that sort of thing. So it kind of cut down the conversation when you attempted to tell people what you were doing and either they weren't interested in writing at all or the kind of writing they were interested in just simply didn't match up with what this stuff was turning out as. But I just, I really enjoyed it, I felt comfortable and felt that I could do it well, I think that's probably the main reason. Okay, Lords of the Starship came out in 1967 and it was, as you mentioned, it's kind of pessimistic decadent societies, entropy is about maximized both socially and physically. That would be something which now we could, we would call probably a new wave quote unquote. Were you influenced by people like J.G. Ballard and Michael Morkock and the people that wrote them the new wave science fiction, very British? Yeah, I thoroughly impressed by Ballard's stuff, not really Morkock too much. Paul Anderson, his adventures, I remember they were quite impressive. I especially like to get back to the contradiction, the survival of what our contemporary society is, its survival into a totally unexpected, hopefully unexpected society and society of decline. That in a way, and maybe this is a cheap reason for doing it, but it allows the aesthetics of what I view to be our science and technology, even though it has failed, I certainly don't blame what happened to bring about the societies that are present in the first book, but they failed to stop them from occurring, but they did survive in fragments and I'd like to think that it acquired some kind of a tragic heroism by what they were doing. The societies, the bad societies that were in the first book, and really in the second, were really caused by whatever causes the bad society and simple stupidity. The artifacts, which if we would think back, I'm just trying to remember you're my contemporaries, so you can remember this great day of the 60s and so on. The artifacts that I enjoyed writing about, the ships in the aircraft and the devices in the science and industry, they remain in isolation. They're usually beset. The people who are allied with them are if not heroic and they're not as bad as the other folks and that kind of threw them fragments into a contract but I at least I believe made them a little on the heroic side because they battled against the inevitable and I really like that. This idea of the society constructing a starship which is going to take centuries to complete, I know you were a history major, is there any kind of historical precedent for that on a much smaller scale that gave you the idea? No, not at all. The idea itself here I'm really trying to think back because the individual suggestions you get when you're thinking about trying to start a story and you're gathering in the hooks and suggestions that pop up can be so minor that I'm just trying to think back and I can't really remember any similar historical parallel although I'm sure it's been tried and I guess some terms have come to mind although as much as a social purpose is any expression of a religious ideal or a field of civil engineering. I think what it came out as is first of all just the sheer image of something that spectacular and given the image then I thought well how can we make a contradictory and it became contradictory by turning the hope into the eventual reason of ruin and it proceeded along those lines nothing that I'm thinking of in my as a reader of history I don't think it's suggested that that's the way the idea evolved. It's a very entertaining book because it did evolve as it was being written and a lot of fun. And you were a sophomore in college that was written. Right. Did you get encouragement from your peers, your professors, did they know what you were doing? Well my English professor, a very fine fellow named Norman Fildes in the freshman year I showed some of my short stories to and he was one of the few people who said this is pretty good stuff so I'm going to keep at it. The problem I had with Kenyon was that the English department was so good I was a little scared of it. That's another reason why I stayed as a history major. The encouragement I had just to people generally what I related to them were pretty encouraging but it wasn't what you might say a literary environment in the sense that in my everyday the people I was in eternity and in class and so on like that there wasn't any seething hot bit of you know literary endeavor what are you doing, what are you trying to say and all that sort of nonsense. It was being built and there was interest and I was able to talk about it and at least the interest was there. It was a men's college so the social structure was considerably simplified over a very small men's college too. So the social structure was considerably simplified I gather over what would have been a comparable large co-ed university and even though the social forms weren't there the eccentricity was and that I think is what helped it along and maybe even allowed it to grow in what I think what I hope was a nice kind of twisting and unexpected way as far as the plot and the setting and so on goes. As far as my mother of course is great encouragement when I was ready as far as high school goes my English teacher in my senior year in honors English was quite definite after showing some of my stuff that I could not write. So that was a lot of encouragement from that. And of course at law school nobody reads so they hardly have any idea what writing is and that wasn't any encouragement at all. But by then I was pretty much worried about myself. How does a college sophomore then get his manuscript published? Did you have any extra problems with that? Well this is this I was kind of lucky when I did my amateur...are you still there? Yeah I can hear you fine. I was pretty lucky I did a little amateur market research and immediately saw it during those days that Ace Paperbacks was easily publishing the greatest volume of titles and I had some very good authors and they had a lot of real thinkers. So I thought well obviously that's the place to go and my family is as I said outside of Philadelphia and during one vacation my sophomore or even junior year I simply put the only final copy of it I had in the paper bag and left it off at the desk. And with a letter I went back to college and a month or two later my parents called me up, called me up, had an offer a nice letter from Donald Wilhine the editor to publish it with more money than I'd ever seen in one place before. Which is not much but it was a really nice thing. I had a pretty good time at it and then it came out. So that sounds a little you know, shot in the dark that's exactly what it was. That makes it sound easy. I was lucky. Donald Wilhine's a really first-rate guy and I certainly enjoyed all the dealings I've had with him. And obviously he's got wonderful taste. Okay out of the mouth of the dragon as I read it was said in the same milieu. Did you conceive of it or the basic idea why you were finishing Lord of the Starship or did it just spring out by itself? Well it came after Lord of the Starship and I was kind of wondering it was actually suggested by, at least as I remember the sequence, it was suggested by a story by Faulkner called The Bear and as I remember it in that story there was just a little bit, not terribly inventive, but I made an impression on it. God creates man and then watches and horrors a man who runs around and does all these unexpected, terrible things. Well that's what I mean, thinking that obviously God created a great number of other things too, time for one and the course of the universe and what happens if they got equally out of control. That allowed, well the next step from there of course is to begin a story with what was supposed to have been the end of the world, Armageddon, and then show how time and the arrange plan of society, or pardon me, the universe for that matter, got progressively more chaotic and out of hand and what does one do in such an environment? Of course I was real depressed when I was read, but the action basically revolved around this society trying to operate in what was becoming a progressively more random and blindly vicious kind of universe, where even the physical laws were getting out of hand and then eventually reaching what was meant to be both symbolic and a literal way to end time, end time by killing everything, that's when the hero at the end assumes a I guess an Antichrist figure in essence that's the universe, or that's the ocean as a life force. Really, I hope it didn't sound that ponders on the rest, but there is a basic symbolistic underline, underframe to a lot of it. It also had a little idea in that, I think, which may have also come up from the first, that in line with the orders of creation, you'd say that well, God with the motivating force creates man in time, or rather, well he creates time, of course, first, and then man in the physical universe, and then the next level down is when man creates machine, as in his little area of sub-creation, and then when the creations of divine creations fail to work correctly and get out of hand, and it's up to man and his sub-creation, the machine, to if not correct it, then at least bring some kind of relief from it, and that's what they do. I try to encourage people to read your work, although I don't loan my books out because I'm a collector and they're getting old. But I don't, the potential suicides are the depressed people. I don't encourage them to read it at the time. Like I said, I just can't get the humor in there. I've got to try that more. Yeah, because it starts out with failure by Rupert Brooke, which is not real uplifting, and then goes to revelations, and then on from there. Yeah, it really didn't cut a lot of monster with dates, either, I'll tell you that. Yeah. The image I wanted to talk to you about of Cavendish's talking skeleton, that stuck with me since I read it. And that really blew me away. I don't like to ask how people got ideas, but how the hell did you get that idea? It just seemed to be a good thing to do. If the Antichrist is going towards some kind of crucifixion of the universe, might as well have a last supper, and he just happened to be at what was originally an old battlefield, so I kind of screwed up my courage with a...well, screwed up my courage, and had a couple beers and sat down and wrote it that way. It was a very obvious parallel way of supper. The idea of the artificial larynx in the Christ figure, Tim and I are the figures, I think it was name one, that itself is a repeat of the idea of these sub-creations of God, man, machine, and when the top level fails, then the bottom level has to carry the burden, however clumsily or imperfectly. And when the guy dies, his machinery keeps on talking, and actually ends up telling the truth. So how it came about was it didn't really...it was just kind of a progressive thing. That's continually... I suppose it's the thing that brings one or leads me back to writing. It just feels good, even though it's hard. It's like running every day. I don't do that every day either. But it's the excitement that when you start doing these things, you really...at least I can't, I can't plan a story in advance. I don't outline things. I have basic ideas, concepts, and rough ideas of character, and what's going to happen for at least a measurable portion of the story. But once you get started, just the background of the furniture that you're describing, instead of constructing the physical world that the characters are moving through, that so often suggests something new and unexpected. And it never happens, of course, until you sit down and actually do it, because then you haven't picked out the detail that suggests the next move. The artificial larynx on the Christ figure out of the mouth of the dragon was just in line with this basic idea. Well, you know, the guy is...he's trying to be a good Christ, and he's trying to tell his revelation. But he gets caught in the battle, the battle on the burn, which is even before the Armageddon, and you know, he gets a voice shot out. It's the very tool he was going to use to rouse righteousness again. Well, the man comes along and tries to give him something almost as good. And in its way, it turns out to be not as good as the first, the natural voice, but it has its own virtues. First of all, it survives the Christ's death, and secondly, like I said, it actually ends up telling the truth. So that's...you know, I can't say that I found something or somebody said something to me, I think what happened, and it just sat in and wrote it, and that's the way the aesthetics, or the furniture, or the background, or the layout of some initial scenes suggested themselves, and the direction the story went in. That's one of the great senses of discovery you get when you're writing, and one of the real enjoyment. And it's also something that people don't write, and of course they don't write, so this never happens, so they're not convinced that it will happen, so everybody can clue...well, a lot of people can clue they can't, so they never do. Even for people who have written such things to themselves, it's a real, real easy, even though you remember that this is the way it almost is. Well, it very often works, as I'm saying inevitably or invariably, but it's not that. But it certainly works often enough to try it again, but convincing yourself that it's going to work one more time is awful hard, and it's still a grind just to get there and put the paper in, and start telling who's in the room and how's he dressed. You don't really start finding the little clues to what's going to happen next, but you do that. Both of these books are critically acclaimed. I don't remember reading any bad reviews, in fact, all the reviews have been laudatory. Would you just as soon write a critically acclaimed book as one that makes a million dollars, I mean, let alone, assuming that you're comfortable and that you don't need a million dollars, but is there some satisfaction there? Well, I really don't think that I have enough either craft or talent to squander doing either one or the other. The books that were written were the ones that I wanted to write. Unfortunately, I don't have to write for a living, although perhaps if I did, I might be doing something a lot more intense. So what I'm extremely gratified is that I'm extremely gratified that people say you still remember the darn thing. That really makes it a lot of it still worthwhile. But as far as the difference between just one address the critics, just one address whatever one conceives to be the upper crust of literary sensibility or just one go for the great unwashed, gee, I don't know if anybody can really make that conscious choice. The idea of the polished hack is a great one, but I don't think there's all that many of them around. There are people that have caught on. Harold Rawls, of course, comes right to mind, and there are people who write very well-acclaimed and moderately successful ones like John Gardner, who just died a couple days ago. But I think basically they simply write what they think is correct, and if they do that they're going to do a good job, and even if it's a piece of hack work, at least it will be a good piece of hack work, and they'll hold together in some coherent fashion. And if a fellow wants to do something that appears to be a bit harder, and then of course equates that with the too often with literary endurance or artistic endurance, then he's going to. The point is to do a good story. If you do the good story, you think the good story is then I think either way it turns out. And if it's critically acclaimed and still well remembered, gee, that's probably not as much as you could ask for, the $1 million bucks, that's not bad either. Okay, we'll move on to the Day Star. You were in law school when you wrote the Day Star? Well actually I started that on numerous occasions. I started it, I think while I was still in college. One reason why is that the person I was dating at the time was convinced having read the first two that I could not write anything in the least bit nice, and this is going to prove her wrong. I began to think she was right when I didn't get the right word on it. So after numerous false starts, it just kind of lay around with an essential idea until the end of law school. I was in New York University at the Law School of Washington Square, and Don Mulheim was still at that time at DAW, or pardon me, Hays before he went to a New American Library and formed a name under DAW. And I tried and I tried. It always turned out a little short and really pretty big. Can I say a nasty word on there? Go right ahead. We don't have to put it on, but go ahead and say it. Okay, well the funny thing is, and one thing I really liked, because it made me feel like a real pro and like I knew what I was doing, is I went up and after he said we couldn't use it, it was framed in the children's story originally, and I had to straight ahead and I said well, you know, we worked before together in two degrees. What's the problem with it? He said well you know, it's kind of rough because it really doesn't suit any of our audience. It's certainly not a children's story. It's much too complicated for that, and it's not really a science fiction story. So it really doesn't address our customary audience. I said, well, gee whiz, what do I do with it? Any suggestions? He kind of leaned back in his chair and waved. He said oh, throwing some of that scientific bullshit, you know how to do it. And I started talking a little bit after that, and after about five minutes, we had a little discussion. We had an idea that eventually, well right there became the idea of the time wind blowing through the various worlds that were arranged in the fashion of the novelist shelf and unifying them. And from there, I think that landed a real note of coherency to what was going on, and went back, rewrote it, and that's all. And it came out under the DAW level. So that was a real nice little bit. I really enjoyed that. This book seemed a lot more allegorical than the others. They were more of the straight science fantasy. I don't know if allegorical is the right word. I'm not an English major, but just a little more magical and whimsical than the others. That's the original thrust of it. It was meant to be much more of the idea of the dream world being more concrete than the waking world, and of multiple dream worlds beyond the one of immediate sleep. And then of course the ghost can move back and forth because he is a dream character. And then the hero becomes progressively more of a dream character himself, and he can move back and forth through these worlds until he comes to this great shining city, you know, a parent, and finds out what's going on. Of course at the end, he ends his own little ruin and a little bit of despair because it is an actual live book, so I couldn't let anybody go happy. But it was originally intended as a children's story, and I hope it didn't turn out to be two overwrought, or two overblown, or two prolet. But that was the ephemeral kind of instruction to retain throughout throughout its course. To me it seems like you have a little preface where you say something. This is the way things were once explained to me, and that seems kind of like a bridge between your old stuff because it's got the symbol of the solitary machine lost during the route of a long dead army. And then you move to this kind of dreamy book, and that almost seemed like a bridge to me when I read it from your old stuff to your new stuff, which may be reading too much into it. No, I think you're correct. It's also as I felt at the time, because most discrepancies were for the people in law school. And I was kind of wondering where my own perspective was going at that moment. And also this book had been planned, or I had been writing it off and on for three years. So it seemed to be a little bit of my own sentiment the way I felt at the time. I thought the production, the cover, the George Barr cover, and the George Barr illustrations throughout the book, that was a pretty classy package that Dawg doesn't seem to do that anymore. How do you feel as an author, looking at your work and seeing the illustrations and that sort of thing? Are they, as you imagined them? Oh yes, yes. Very flattering, very thrilling. Always nice to see your imagination visualized as well as I guess, verbalized. And it's always nice to know that somebody else read it too. And it's found that even though the guy was walking, that it had some enough of a power of suggestion that it's translated over into somebody else's imagination. As far as paintings go, I still, my absolute favor was the first cover on the piece paperback edition of Lord and the Starship. That I really liked. Although I have to say that all four have, well the first two were reprinted to Hardcover in France last year in a single Hardcover volume and then the second third and fourth should be out right about now, I believe by French publishing house called OPTA. And they've just done a beautiful job in their own illustrations and redoing the map of the world and stuff like that. So that's always very, very thrilling. Okay, then the Siege of Wonder, which seemed to kind of get back to the same theme as the original two books, The Far Future. But it had the fantasy element, much more of a fantasy element with the magic versus the science. Right, well it was a very clear cut. I wrote that again, this is to put it in something of a social context. Let's see, 74 or 5, when I suppose all the hippies were going into retirement. But again, the technology was not highly thought of. But I believe that, and as I still do right now, there's a great deal of romance to it. A great deal of beauty and as I said, it's explicit, it's not explicit heroism. And it's used. And to keep that in mind I was reading a book, I think it was Algus Butterys I think, you know, possibly. Anyway, a book of criticism, science fiction, and a history, a critical history called the Billion Years' Freed. That's Brian Oldis. Yeah, very good book. And I, you wrote the other point out, the very obvious fact that there isn't that terribly much of a difference between fantasy, classical fantasy sword and sorcery, and science fiction. Even Space Stopper science fiction, because each one ultimately depends on the impossible before the action. On the one you have Turning Lefty Gold and the Prince of the Frog, which is a physical impossibility. On the other you have physical ships shooting the speed of light which as far as we know is an equal impossibility. So they really both proceed from the same suspension of disbelief as Coleridge would say. But very often you do get not so much anymore, but you do get this artificially sharp distinction between fantasy on the one hand and the Lord of the Rings, and let's say the analog school of science fiction. Given that, it occurred to me that why not just cut out the shilly-shallying and just have a direct collision between the two. And that's where you get the war between science and magic. The way I envisioned it, again although it has an ending that's typical for me with despair and all that, but the way I thought about that book was really, if you remember Bill Maldon's cartoon character is Joe and Willie. It's kind of like Joe and Willie meet Elric where you do have the grand delinquents of fantasy confronted by the very real and very truly destructive or powerful, but by the same token I think more humane forces of science and technology. At least that's the way I saw it. And the direct collision of the two, neither are particularly nice guys, although I found, and I think they came across the greater sympathy and side of science. Even though what they were doing was ultimately self-destructive or dehumanizing, which is a little contradictory, I'd say that's more humane, but perhaps even in that sense feel more humane than what magic has allowed it to become. Again, that didn't cut a lot of monsters in print. Okay, you were in Idaho by the time this one was published. Oh yes, that was written entirely out here. Okay. I had a job on it right back. What I want to do now, what I better do is turn my tape over. I have one tooth, I have four more questions on my list if you're not tired of this already. Let me turn my tapes over and get them. If you want to take a break or something, go ahead, this will take me about two minutes. Okay.

segments.text: Okay, the tapes were on.
Mark, could you give me a little bit of your background, how you grew up,

Sure. I was born in 1946 in New Jersey,
and grew up in the suburbs outside of Philadelphia.

a lot of books around at all times, and was encouraged to direct my
interest in that direction.
As far as starting writing goes, that was
almost seemed to be the thing to do.
When I was in grade school and began writing
short stories, it was a good play and release for
imagination, and I certainly enjoyed it, and
the editors didn't share my enthusiasm, however, and I
have had not entirely a lot of success in short stories, and that effect the only one
I've ever published was Soul, when I finally got out here to Idaho
in any event, I wrote

has really quite a history.
My area of study has always been
the liberal arts, the sciences I'm frankly trying to be much too
challenging and much too much work.
What I do as a science fiction only in the sense that it's
I'd say more fantasy than science fiction.
I don't really have that much of a grasp of hard science, not both
but I certainly appreciate the aesthetics of it,
and that figures in, I take a great deal in the four novels
of the effort. I was very fortunate
at Kenyon because I finally decided that
this was not going to sell short stories, and in my sophomore year began my first novel

and came out with paperbacks,

that apparently
survived in the marketplace, since being reprinted
